Good old times before Ubisoft discovered how to spell [b]‚Äúmicrotransaction‚Äù[/b] in some of their games like Assassin‚Äôs Creed.

This IP has been through a lot. From the highest of highs with Heroes of Might and Magic III to the hell that was Heroes VI. The studio Unfrozen has taken up a mantle that once seemed impossible to get right yet they did it. In fact, they got it more right than ever before.

Olden Era has revived the IP. This is, without a doubt, the best modern Heroes of Might and Magic game we could have hoped for. Here are the reasons this game is amazing and why anyone should try it:

Pros
‚Ä¢ Feels like home

This looks and feels exactly like how a modern take on HoMM should feel. Anyone who has played a HoMM game will instantly know what to do the moment they load in. You have your faction, your hero(es), your units and now you decide what to do with them. The team absolutely nailed the classic HoMM feeling.

‚Ä¢ Distinct personalities

A major gripe I always had with HoMM III was how ugly some heroes were. Some looked so weird that it took away from the joy of playing them. Olden Era fixes this. Heroes here are cool, unique, stylish, strange, charming there‚Äôs something for everyone.
Want cool guys? Ister, Leon, or Bulwark are there.
Want something pretty? Funerella, Motley, or Zenith.
Need a weirdo? Sunny Rauktol, Iron Master, or Lia.
They nailed hero personality and identity.

‚Ä¢ Useful units

In HoMM III every faction has at least one unit you never use, sometimes two or three. Zombies, dwarves, dendroid are never used.
In Olden Era, while some units are certainly better than others, none feel useless.
There‚Äôs a real argument for rushing Dread Knights in Necro, going all-in on Inquisitors, or just running around with Black Dragons.
Most units have abilities that add depth to combat, and some even help you outside of battle. Fights are now the most interesting they‚Äôve ever been in the series.

‚Ä¢ Two upgrades. Duh!

How HoMM VI and VII didn‚Äôt include two upgrades per creature is beyond me, especially when the feature already existed in HoMM V.
This single feature makes every unit 10x more interesting.
Some upgrade paths change roles entirely (like ranged vs. melee), while others offer meaningful stat and ability differences. It gives you real strategic choice and yes, it makes a huge difference.

‚Ä¢ Modern options

A modern HoMM game should come with modern features.
Love the classic ‚Äúmany heroes, explore everything, chain armies around the map‚Äù style? It‚Äôs here.
Prefer a faster, single-hero mode where death = game over? You can pick it.
Want to draft units, items, and abilities and just fight? Click the button.
Three unique modes, all instantly accessible. No lobby searching, no DMing randoms. Just play.

Cons:

The Cavalier unit is‚Ä¶ very ugly, haha. The upgrades look great, but the base Cavalier could really use a redesign.

That‚Äôs it.

I‚Äôve seen the negative comments: ‚ÄúIt looks ugly,‚Äù ‚Äúmobile graphics,‚Äù ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell what‚Äôs what.‚Äù
Art style is subjective you‚Äôll either let it grow on you or you won‚Äôt.
But to the people complaining that they can‚Äôt tell which units are ranged on the map or that ore looks like mushrooms(???):
Come on. You had no idea what anything was in HoMM III the first time you booted it up 25 years ago. Don‚Äôt pretend you instantly recognized a random swamp as a Hydra dwelling, or knew Medusa Queens were ranged the first time you saw them.
Just like back then, familiarity takes time. Let it breathe.

UI improvements, unit backgrounds, Temple unique skill and Necromany those things are already confirmed as being changed, so I‚Äôm not counting them as negatives. The IP is in good hands with Unfrozen. Give them room to work.

Everything I‚Äôve said comes from the demo and playtest. Nothing more, nothing less. The game will release in Early Access and stay there for at least a year before 1.0 drops. This will give Unfronze all the time they need to make sure this game stays around for many many years!

This is the revival the series deserved.

Scattered thoughts after the demo:
Good:
- Some units can still be uninspiring initially, but overall they are growing on me, as I come to remember which are which. I appreciate that there are no units like the peasants or zombies from Heroes 5 that just feel kinda... lame?
- I like the idea of the new factions. The Hive is an insect hive mind (haven't had a chance to play yet), and the Schism are cultists summoning horrors from the frigid wastes, which tickles my Lovecraft bone.
- I like that they took the idea of skill synergies from Heroes 5, but kept it simple. You get skills (basic, advanced, expert), and on advanced and expert you get to select a subskill. Some subskills get their bonuses enhanced if you have another skill (or for some magic skills - just more schools of magic), and that's it. Simple, easy to refer to.
- The game has a cozy vibe while playing it. Subjective, but it was easy to spend time here.
- The law system is pretty cool. Each faction can accumulate specific bonuses over time - unit generation, strength, certain spell power. I like the customization.
- Movement is simplified. No more movement based on your slowest unit. No movement for picking up resources. I like it, but opinions can vary.

Neutral:
- I have no idea where the balance is in this game. Necromancy seems a bit underwhelming? Somehow I feel that the Nightshade school of magic does, too? But maybe I just haven't used it right. I don't really plan on playing MP, but still.

Bad?
- Alchemical dust (extra material used for upgrading artifacts and creating some buildings) seems a bit restrictive at times, as it blocks unit creation.
- Not a fan of the way you find the grail. Cool idea in concept, but the AI will never manage it, and you kinda have to cheese it.
- Are the hero portraits AI art? They kinda have that vibe. Kinda sucks to suspect that everywhere now, but if so - ew.
- AI is better, but it still needs work. If hexed with twilight (can't use ranged attacks), enemies just stand still. AI launches suicidal attacks against you. PLEASE DEVS I hope you program in that AI uses surrender/flee mechanic. Hell, make it a checkbox. I want the AI to be a challenge.

All in all, good job. It does feel like the people who made this game loved the previous ones, and had a good vision

Pros(+):

Neutral(+/-):

- Law system. Kinda feels Civilization-like because of it and I'm not sure what I feel about it. Here however... it kinda matters, because the law skilltree you get depends on the starting castle(faction) you chose.
I like it for the favour of more meaningful choices, but I kinda dislike it for the fact that it kinda forces you to play the strategy you chose early on...

- AI in the battle - sometimes it plays smarter (ignoring obvious baits) than the one in HoMM3 but sometimes... its way more stupid - e.g: ignoring taunt till it passes or ignoring twilight(?) (forgetfulness) till it passes.

- AI on the overworld does not pose any challenge even on biggest map and highest difficulty. I think AI in HotA plays better than this one.

- Hero subclass. This requires you to pick 5 predetermined skills (which you didnt really want to pick) in order to receive a game-breaking or useless (depending on hero class) ability. But lets say you go for this subclass that makes all spells cost no mana(game breaking), right? Yeah, well, now you have 4/5 of those skills? Great. Welcome to 8th pick of skill. Oh, you didnt have enough faith in RNGods? Sorry, but you are stuck with useless skills and broken hero which will never get a subclass.

- SERIOUSLY - did someone from the Unfrozen team played Necropolis in HoMM3 and went like "man, this castle is way too weak, lets buff it in our game!"!?!?!?!? WHAT THE FK, BRO!?
Necropolis is even STRONGER than in HoMM3, like holy fk, what is wrong with you!?

HOMM is a game like chess, in a way. Its core concept is so solid that changing it too much reduces its quality, and doing the same thing can get boring to many people. Olden Era (OE if I reference it again) goes in directions that feel both fresh and obvious to me. Games feel engaging and rewarding, combat is back to being hexagonal boards, skills cater more towards long term progression as they also provide new passives you can pick when upgrading them, and heroes have skills of choice depending on who they are and how you want to build them. Of course, randomization is part of the mix, so getting a perfect combo of the skills you want can be tricky, but I don't mind.

If you've played HOMM as a kid, like many of us did with our parents or siblings, or if you're new to the genre, give this demo a go. I think it's the long awaited return of an absolute classic of PC gaming, that can be loved by honestly anyone who loved fantasy, strategy games and great music.

[h1][b][i]"HOMM: Olden Era Demo"[/i][/b][/h1]
[h2][u]Overview[/u][/h2]
I'm not a huge fan of the HOMM series, but the demo was extremely interesting to learn. And the initial tutorial pointed out the main mechanics and allowed me to recall others that can be controlled during the game.
This game feels like a remake of the third legendary part of Heroes of Might & Magic, in addition to some mods for new creatures and factions. Familiar objects, units and music - allow you to recall some memories from the past, which will further absorb you in to the game.
Despite the lack of a campaign, multiplayer mode and a limited list of factions - in all other respects the game offers a full arsenal to try out - and that's cool.
As for the full release of the game - I'll have to wait a few years for the price to drop a bit :)
[h2][u]Pros:[/u][/h2]
[list]
[*]Low PC requirements for a comfortable game, which will allow you to run it on most systems.
[*]Three main game modes, which I only watched on YouTube, namely: Arena or as it is called in the community "Luck Test" (where we choose a hero, his talents, artifacts and army), Classic (I think the name speaks for itself) and my favorite - OutCast (Controlling only one hero throughout the entire game).
[*]Wide variability in building your army. By gaining 2nd level for each unit, you can choose a certain specialization for your style of play.
[*]Beautiful game design. Cities, map, units, artifacts - everything looks cool.
[*]Additional characteristics to second-level and third-level talents. Which add even more variability in hero builds. My favorite was: "You get a concentration charge when your units attack" and "You get a concentration charge when your units take damage". A very cool combination that allows your units to almost constantly use active abilities.
[*]A wide list of spells that I never learned in 15 hours, as I only used some of them. In the tutorial, there was an opportunity to gain an advantage in battle only due to spells and correct positioning, but in practice in a match - I never tried it.
[*]The section of laws, which gives the opportunity to strengthen your faction, both economically and militarily.
[*]The generation and position of items are sometimes hidden. Yes, you can press "Alt" and see all the active points, but it is quite interesting to study each fragment visually on your own.
[/list]
[h2][u]Cons:[/u][/h2]
[list]
[*]During battle, the hero's banner overlaps the display of the received damage for the unit in the upper corner of the field.
[*]The menu for viewing equipped artifacts does not have a filter by sets. When you have a bunch of artifacts, you have to check the description of each individual artifact to make sure: "Does it fit for set or not?".
[*]While the hero is moving along the route, you cannot use the right mouse button to view the map at the same time. The hero will simply stop.
[*]Some spells and units do not have sound effects. That's what this demo is for - to fix all this.
[*]The middle and late part of each match turns into a "snowball". And you are actually just collecting resources and strengthening your army, while the AI quickly calculates the outcome of each match (usually in our favor). In my opinion, it would be nice to have the need to enter the battle in manual mode in some cases.
[/list]

I had a problem how to review this demo as Olden Era is still in development and there is no Steam's neutral review option.
While I enjoyed OE I am a singleplayer gamer first, so I decided to give "not recommended" review.

First pros:
+ It's not "a mobile" game, no matter what some desprate "fans" would want to you belive. It's fully HoMM game with its spirit. Sure, it's not HoMM3 game and hopefully will never be, as trying to emulate third part of franchise was never a successful idea.

+ I liked it. There still is "one more turn" feeling from the demo. Heroes development is a much improvement from H3's times but still need a lot of work.

+ Town screens have some issues but overall are beautiful and "live". You can see citizens moving around cities, something which was missing since HoMM1.

+ Alternative creature upgrades. Just like in last previous games, you can choose one of two alternatives and change them during gameplay.

+ Lots of spells and magic in the demo seems overpowered. They're not balanced yet and I find it's a good thing as nerfing things to the ground in search of mythical "balance" always leads to a game being boring.

+ New magic system. While you still get random spells in magic guilds, now you can pay to research/unlock missing ones. You can also can upgrade spells by using resources or by building more guilds (each additional doubled spell count as another spell's level).

+ Combat seems to be fun and units have a lot of nice and useful abilities. Same for each factions.

+ Lots of artifacts which can be upgraded to be even more powerful, althrough you won't have much resources to do that in short games/on a small maps.

+ Demo is very easly moddable and I guess the game will stay the same.


Now cons:
-  While there is "one more turn" syndrome, the game becomes boring very quickly. You test each faction, most of heroes, alternative upgrades, spells, etc. but after that, Olden Era doesn't have anything to hold you for any longer. Sure, it's a demo and not a full game but nevertheless you get bored very quickly.

- Maps. There are not maps per se but random templates focused on PvP aspect of game. They fail for singleplayers as while there have plenty places to visit with your heroes, their main focus is to destroy enemies ASAP. Each starting zone in a template is also a mirror of enemy's starting zone, so you know what to except. You also start with additional neutral (mostly) non-protected city or two in your zone, plenty of mines and creature dwellings, and lots and lot of resources to level up your city and army very quickly. That's very PvP mindset and there is no time to explore whole map unless you really want and prelong the game just to do this.

- While factions have unique units and mechanics, you play them as for now nearly the same. Sure, first week may be a little different but after that? Just gather your troops and roll out, crashing every enemy under feet of your army.

- Battles. Current autobattles are quicker and you lost less troops as the game can't calculate real losses and just make the number up. AI is still not good and only win if the player don't rush at it as it can then enmasse more creatures from external dwellings and castles.

- Lots of spell but not all are useful. Damage spells become less revelant as the game progress and overall they are weak. You also need to upgrade them to get their fully potential. While it's better than having "x magic" skill which makes a low level spell a mass version, it's still IMO inferior to magic system from HoMM2 and HoMM4, where mass spells were higher tier magic.

- Too many artifacts. Most of them are worthless (common and rare categories) and you don't have resources to upgrade them as you need these resources to ugrade buildings in your cities. Artifact sets are also underwelming and not worth to complete.

- Faction Law system. Basically a very limited research "tree" which you unlock with battles and town buildings. There is no relation between perks, so you only needd to unlock new level to be able to buy next perks. You can't buy them all so in the end you would always choose (nearly) the same laws. Laws UI is too small and ugly.

- Skills and heroes specializations. Some are overpowered, other not worth to bother. There are five sub-skills for each skill but you can only choose two and sometimes the choice is so obvious, you just wonder, how this even passed during game desing?

- Tragic UI. Too small and hard to read icons, icon colors that look nearly the same, buttons placed all around screen instead in one place, lack of information when you point mouse curson on it, lack of R-click options for many, many things, etc.

- Adventure Map readability. It's hard to tell which object is a map decoration and which is visitable. There are also resources you just can't notice because RNG placed them behind some rock or tree. There is an ALT key to highlight them but if you need to press a special key to see a map object, then something is wrong with your design.

- Creature and heroes design and portraits. It's hard to tell, which alternative upgrade you will fight and it was initially hard to tell, which creature you are buying. Fortunately devs changed a little that but the problem still exists. There is also a problem with portraits. Heroes portraits are hand-drawned (sometimes good, sometimes bad) but creature portraits are 3D in-game miniatures which IMO look worse. I think this clash of different graphic styles is the main reason why Olden Era is called "a mobile game". This and UI.

- PvP focus. It's clear to me this game is first and mostly focused on PvP games. Map templates instead of Random Generated Maps or scenarioes designed by humans/devs (althrough devs promised these features will be in final game), game mods for PvP players, game focus on combat and not enough of map exploration, heroes development, economy, etc., all these just point that devs focused on PvP aspect of HoMM games, especially HoMM3.

- Some red flags from devs behavior.
Early access was postponed IIRC twice and as for time of this review doesn't have a date.
There is also a case of devs calling themselves "true fans" - if you are a fan, you don't need to reasure yourself that you are "true" fan (do you need a certificate for this?).
I find also strange that for "true" fans devs sometimes behave like they didn't play other games than H2-3 and 5.
It's personal opinion but I have a feeling that Olden Era started on backbone of H7 and went from there to build its own self. It's nothing wrong in but many "new" features of OE were already present in H7 or even earlier but Unfrozen somehow "forgets" to aknowledge this.
On the other hand, Unfrozen really "hears" the fandom and make lots of changes so it's not that bad but nevertheless red flags are here and can't be ignore.
The last of red flags is that Might and Magic franchise is owned by Ubisoft and while I have some doubts in Unfrozen, I have many, many more doubts in Ubisoft and I fear they can screw the game just before the release (like introducing a DRM) and devs would have nothing to say in that case.

Overall I'm not against Olden Era and will see, how it would be developed futher but I don't recommend to pre-order or buy it in first day. Just wait and see.

This game takes inspiration from Heroes 5, and includes many changes introduced by it, but fails to bring the most important change: unit action rate (which was tracked in Heroes 5 by initiative). In this game units take turns acting, so a zombie acts as often as a dragon.

Some good features kept or introduced:

Units have two upgrades.
Hero skills have specialisations.
Heroes themselves can reach one of two potential masteries.
Items can be part of sets.
Hexagonal tiles in combat.
Many creatures have usable abilities.
Besides upgrading towns, players can also upgrade the realm. Some of these upgrades are shallow, but others can be game changers (for example, the ability to construct two buildings per turn)
Castle fortification upgrades can also specialise.
Items can be upgrades.
The graphical engine is really good.
I liked the draft hero build and follow up battle mode.

Some awful features, besides the lack of HMM5 initiative driven action rate:

The resource system was simplified, which is a trend in the age of games targeting the common denominator.
Combat maps are tiny.
In-combat tactical deployment is basic. Changes don't save between fights.
Creature dwelling units can not be recruited inside towns, like in HMM5.
Faction differences are token at best. Nothing like HMM5. The system could not have been made more shallow if the developers tried.
The art design suffers from a "samey" look for units, compounded by units having mostly the same size and the same narrow colour pallet...
The art design suffers from a bland colour pallet. This applies to the world and combat maps. Things blend in and tracking what can be interacted visually is exhausting. One has to keep Alt pressed at all time to highlight interactibles.
Combat unit abilities use a shared resource pool and have obnoxious cooldowns. Truly shameful compared to HMM5.
Hero skill specialisation are bland, shallow or both. Again, nothing like HMM5. The system was clearly an attempt at simplifying role playing and hero growth down to the mobile audience common denominator level.
Spells are bland or just awful, again nothing like HMM5 or even Heroes 3.

There were other features I liked or disliked, but these were minor.

At this stage, it is unlikely that changes will occur to the more critical issues shown above, hence why I do not recommend the game. Play the superior Heroes 5 Tribes of the East instead...

I am writing this review as a massive HOMM3 fan, so perhaps it is doomed to be a bit biased from the very beginning. The game has generated a lot of hype recently and I do love the way they are promoting it, especially in terms of their YouTube channel. I do think that the creators have very big shoes to fill when creating a game for this franchise: it is very hard to encompass all the good things about the previous games while still trying to make it feel new, exciting and unique.

Graphics and UI
I did not like the style at the start at all, but it has grown on me a little bit‚Ä¶ I do have to agree with a lot of other gamers and say that it does look a bit ‚Äúmobilesque‚Äù. The graphics on the world screen seem too rich and detailed at times and I know it sounds silly but it just feels overwhelming at times. HOMM3 had that ‚Äúdark‚Äù feel to it that kind of made the game more serious. This one feels like it was designed for children. For me, it‚Äôs sometimes extremely hard to distinguish interactable objects from the background and I find that I would miss certain objects as they blend too much into the background. I never had that problem with any of the previous HOMM games. I would like to see a lot more sharpness in the design in this regard.

Towns
This is quite a disappointment for me in general as all towns sort of feel the same, just different colour pallets. In general, I think a lot of buildings look like figurines from some table top game, just looks fake and out of proportions. Towns also lack sharpness, I feel I‚Äôm not able to distinguish if a building is a dwelling or if its just background. Some dwellings have extremely poor designs as well, for example the Dungeon dragons live in some sort of a temple (?) that looks way too small to even house a single dragon‚Ä¶ Why not have giant caves in the back that you could zoom into and have them flying there in the background? I know it may seem too similar to other HOMM games but I think that would be hundred times better than the current tiny temple. For me, all towns just feel a bit cluttered and lack that grandeur that we all love from the earlier games.

Heroes
I would like to start by saying that I do like the variety of heroes and portrait designs that they have at the moment. Hero backgrounds are missing but I do feel like this is something that will come out eventually when the game is released as it‚Äôs probably one of the last things on the developers to-do-list (fair enough but I am hoping for decent stories and detailed backgrounds so we can fall in love with these heroes!). However, some heroes are clearly stronger than others and I feel like there‚Äôs a lot of imbalance currently. For example some heroes start with very powerful spells, while others have more limited abilities that may only be useful at the start or end-game. I think the worst part for me is the ones that specialise in units: at the moment, all heroes have the same stats and growth for the unit that they specialise in, e.g. the hero with Skeleton specialisation adds the same growth (+2) as the hero who specialises in Dread Knights (+2). Moreover, both of these heroes boost their specialised units stats by the same amounts, i.e. 1 speed, 1 initiative, 20% health and 1 attack/defence for every 3 hero levels. I think it needs a bit of balancing, especially for the growth part as +2 Skeletons/week surely does not equal +2 Dread Knights/week?
Another imbalance lies with the town specific hero abilities I think ‚Äì while I love the fact that heroes have a unique skill depending on their faction, I do not think that they are quite right at the moment. For example, Temple faction gets Ascension, which grants benefits whenever one of your stacks die. So in order to get a benefit, one or more of your stacks need to be completely wiped out first. If the stack does not die, no benefit. In reality, you will be forced to manage your units in a way so you have a lot of 1-unit-stacks so that you can maximise this skill. Might work well at the beginning of a game, but I am not sure how well this might go at late game. Sounds like a lot of micromanagement for me‚Ä¶ Other factions seem to have a lot more straight-forward passive abilities, that don‚Äôt really require you to do anything major, really.

Units
Visually, in general, I think a lot of units lack sharpness. A lot of them seem very detailed but it‚Äôs actually impossible to see all that detail in reality. What I mean by this is resolution and details seem out of proportions. For example, the Cavalry unit in the Temple faction looks like a cheap plastic figurine. Extremely poor design. It makes me not want to even recruit them, I can‚Äôt stand the current design! Other units, however, are quite well designed, like the Vampires or Angels. Sentinels of Glory though, seriously, what is that design? They have wings growing out of their hips it seems? No. In general, very hit and miss in terms of unit design.
Another thing I don‚Äôt like about the units is that the upgrades lack uniqueness in most cases. This game allows for two different upgrades for each unit but for some units it really doesn‚Äôt matter which upgrade you take, your choice will not have a big impact whatsoever. I think this is a missed opportunity really as they could have done something similar to HOMM4 where the choice of your upgrade was permanent and so it did really have a massive impact on your play style. At the very least, they could have made upgrades more different in terms making units melee/ranged, spell caster/ranged/melee, tank/assassin and so on. At the moment, most of the upgrades just feel very similar and boring, why even bother with two different upgrades in this case?
Unit abilities and the Focus mechanic, in my opinion, is a complete mess at the moment. While I do think the Focus mechanic is interesting, some units abilities are clearly better than others, so you will end up never using them, e.g. lower tier units versus high tier units. I think some Focus abilities should just be remade into passive abilities/spells to be honest.

Mage guild/magic
While I do like the current system overall, I think it has its weaknesses. For instance, spells can be unlocked for resources, which is fine, but the problem for me is that some spells are clearly stronger than others, so players will only unlock the main meta ones in reality. The randomness that came with the mage guild is something that provided that excitement I think in the previous games; in this one it just seems a bit too easy and too accessible. I miss the unpredictability!

Last thing I want to mention is something that I absolutely hate in the current version of the game, the Alchemical Dust. This is a super annoying resource that you can only find on the map, trade via a special building using your precious resources or gain by disenchanting artifacts. I played many maps at this stage and I never seem to have enough of this material, which is very frustrating, as this resource is required for certain town upgrades and also spell/artifact upgrades. I do honestly believe that exists only to add that ‚Äúgrind‚Äù factor to the game to make it more difficult and never ending. It‚Äôs a completely unnecessary aspect in my opinion. Either make it more abundant, especially in late games, or make it more precious to acquire but only needed for artifact upgrading. Also, some artifacts seem like they can be upgraded an unlimited amount of time, something I do not approve of. I like games to have finality, some sort of framework. Designing something to have no end I think only creates that unlimited grind possibility, something which I am not here for to be honest.

In general, I think it‚Äôs a very good attempt at a HOMM game but I do think it still needs a lot of work regarding different aspects of it. I have approx. 30 hours played at the moment and I am already bored. Will I buy the full version when it comes out? I honestly don‚Äôt know, perhaps when it‚Äôs on sale...

It is a decent foundation.. It is pretty much Heroes of Might and Magic 5, with a touch of Heroes 3's art style and game design decisions being mixed in, there IS potential.

The good: 
1. The art style for the resources and environment somewhat copy Heroes 3 and 5 - it's not ugly and it has its charm.
2. The potential balance for this game seems pretty solid - no mass slow, no mass haste, armaggeddon can be nullified rather easily and it doesn't deal enough damage to 1 shot everything. Cities with walls feel like fortresses that can deal more damage than ever (you can literally take down 2 dragons each turn and the walls aren't that easy to destroy). Spells are strong, but there's a balance.
3. The law leveling system gives a bit of gameplay variety.
4. The units are somewhat decently designed and each race has its charm.
5. The demo is kinda nice, access to full cities and 5 full maps with the tutorial. 
6. The turn times for opponents are short at release! This is a huge deal for a heroes game!

The bad.
1. The UI and UX aren't good. Upgrading is tedious, you have to go into the upgrade menu separately to upgrade for who knows what reason. The City upgrade system is ugly, while it is functional with lines between buildings to indicate what needs what, it looks messy. Clicking on minions has like an number of small buttons that don't do much (I was looking for an upgrade button but couldn't find it, even though the unit has like 5-6 different buttons to split the stack whenever you click on it). It also lacks the option to choose enemy castles on maps (likely will be fixed in the full version) nor see the single map information.
2. The art style is lacking contrast - all the buildings in the overworld look indistinquishable from each other, it all blends together into a mess, which is especially annoying because you have to pick up units from the dwellings every week and interact with the overworld (you will get used to it, but it isn't as easy to distinguish as Heroes 2, 3, 4, 5). For example, the stables in the overworld looks like a farmhouse, and you will only notice the horses in the farmhouse once you zoom in. The city art is also kinda meh, there are some buildings that will stand out, while others (for example the dreadknight building for necromancers, which is a T6 building) that pretty much blends into the cityscape
3. The focus on dwellings - if you had a Caravan type of building that transported the units from the dwellings each week, it'd be fine, but with the current balance you WILL be lacking in unit production due to the lack of a castle/well that increases unit production, so the game is balanced on getting tons of dwellings (depending on the map), gathering up an army and increasing your army production in the town to build your armies (law system leveling & dwellings together with getting other cities of the same type). Cycling through dwellings each week is tedious and busywork, it would be nice to have more units produced in the city, with a smaller focus on outside dwellings. The overworld's lack of contrasting buildings and a coherent world style adds to this frustration.
4. The AI is broken - I've by now played a total of 3 single player maps on Normal, 3rd highest difficulty and 2nd highest difficulty. The AI has been broken at least 2 of the 3 games. By the 2nd month some enemies still haven't taken the towns that are in their vicinity. They have 1 big hero that they run around with and once they lose it it's GG. They sometimes leave their cities (that I previously noted are crazy strong at defending) with their main hero to attack your vastly superior army (that even the auto battle might win with only minor losses) the decision making is poop on the AI. They often leave cities empty (when even a small defense can deal some damage if they have the walls. Also it feels like on higher difficulties the AI gets a BIT (?) better as the last game I had at the 2nd highest difficulty, the enemies somehow managed to get together a really strong army (far stronger than me), but due to them not upgrading their 20 cave dragons (?) and in general attacking my main army in the city, where even the auto battle gave me the victory, made me scratch my head.
5. The grail fight seems way overtuned (tho not sure if it might be my lack of experience, but I'm more experienced than 90% of the playerbase...) It is an interesting decision to have a dwelling/fight for the grail, but it's basically a fight where the game looks at your army, doubles its size, gives the enemy your hero's spells, increases the enemy hero's stats to be higher than yours, and says "go ahead, give it a shot". It might be possible to abuse the AI in some ways to win that fight (maybe make it use bad spells, bad units, etc) but making you try to cheese the fight defeats this purpose. You could literally just make it a mirror match without big buffs and it'd still be a decent (reasonable) challenge for most players... Not to mention losing half or even most of your main army for the grail is a joke of a decision - no one would think it'd be worth the struggle.
6. The soundtrack is extremely unnoticeable. No emotions nor feelings were evoked with the songs. The city themes in each past classic Heroes game have been major pieces of music that have told you the race's story (or fit in with the vibe of the town at the very least), but in this one, it's just "meh".

Due to the AI issues, the art style and UI issues, I cannot give it a purchase recommendation. I recommend everyone to TRY this demo and for my initial impressions, this game did exceed my low expectations, but it's not one which I would currently play over Heroes 2, 3, 4 or 5. This game will need a lot more love and development time before I'd be able to say that it's at the same level as any of the other good Heroes games.

As a Heroes of Might and Magic game I think it's a 7/10 with potential - but if your previous games were 9/10's and 10/10's, it needs to do a bit better. 


Edit: Also this game WILL NEED online multiplayer lobbies to work as a new competitive Heroes game with something akin to the Warcraft 3/Starcraft 2 online lobbies with chatrooms, ranks, custom games, etc - just having mediocre multiplayer system will not work for this title.. Finally, a GOOD random map generator, needs to be present, because that's where most of the replayability comes from. These things are a must for a modern Heroes game, or else why did you put that much effort into balance if you don't want to make this into a multiplayer game? Also, constantly visiting creature dwellings each week will be crazy annoying in a multiplayer setting.

[h3]A weird amalgamation of older greater titles sprinkled with some odd choices and lazy generated maps to make a toothless cryptid of nostalgia. [/h3]
Just to give some context, I adore the early Heroes of Might and Magic (HoMM) games, and I have spent countless hours of my most formative years taking turns in a dark dungeon moving my little hero on the world map dreaming of strange places filled with monsters, loot and magical opposition. I grew up with HOMM being the perfect game for a hotseat game on the side of hanging out with friends and loved ones. My absolute favourite is HoMM 3 that, in my humble opinion, really nailed the balance between exploration, looting and clever turn based combat. Sure some spells and factions were arguably better than others, but in the end you came for the experience, not the perfectly balanced utopia that has ruined so many games as of late. First and foremost, HoMM: Olden Era is more or less Heroes 3, with some added bits and pieces from later incarnations, and you instantly feel at home in the murky dungeons and sprawling landscapes filled with leprechauns, windmills and castles. However, since I started playing plenty of things kept nagging at me, so here is an easily digestible list of things I liked, felt ‚Äúmeh‚Äù over, and actively disliked..

[h3]The likes![/h3]
[olist]
    [*][b]The tried and tested formula:[/b] As I already stated, this is more or less the formula from HoMM 3. Pick a town, hire some heroes, build up an empire through exploration, expansion and conquest. You instantly get the hang of it if you are a returning player, and this is, and will always be, a great game play loop for all generations!

    [*][b]The music:[/b] I am a soundtrack enjoyer, and with Paul Anthony Romero back onboard the music is a heroesque as it has always been. This made me happy since it was his music that really encapsulated the setting for me. The music (so far) have been great and really works wonder in elevating the theme. Oh, and to be fair, the other composer is Cris Velasco of Mass Effect and God of War fame, credit where credits due.

    [*][b]The flow of battle:[/b] The turnbased combat is as good as it always was, and the addition of a few skillsets that makes the position even more important really elevated the sense of tactical combat, there are more depths to master here and I am sure it will be even more finetuned at launch. 
[/olist]

[h3]The ‚Äúmeh‚Äù![/h3]
[olist]
    [*][b]The amount of troop-types:[/b] This might be a me problem, but the addition of extra differentiation in unit-types really bothers me for multiple reasons. It makes diplomacy so much worse. ‚ÄúOh you triggered a diplomatic victory? Hope you have at least 3 free spaces in your army to slot in all the variations of hell-hounds you just acquired..‚Äù Also, the cities are always cluttered with various units as it is, so I much preferred the old baseline/improved style, but here your mileage may vary‚Ä¶

    [*][b]The elves(alvar):[/b] I will admit I am not up to date on the lore as of late, but in this particular game I feel the same oversaturation of elves in the factions I had in HoMM5. Dungeon lost harpies and evil eyes and got two generic looking humanoids? Sure they are less sexy this time around and I have a love for elves, but that only goes so far. And yes I know the lore around the evil eyes, I just miss my floating brainstems‚Ä¶

    [*][b]The curse of sameness:[/b] Now this is a truly mixed bag. On the overworld map I love parts of it, but some stuff is just bleeding together into a formless mass of background noise‚Ä¶ I can't tell how many times I missed an artifact or a pile of treasure because it was slightly obscured by a small mountain. And when it comes to all the monsters, it is even more confusing, but I assume that will be something you get used to.

 [*][b]The laws:[/b] I really see the potential to this system, even if it is more or less a tech-tree in disguise. My only problem with it is that it feels, as of now, rather min-maxy. Some choices are simply just better then the others and I found myself more or less focusing on the same laws each and every game despite the other variables. But it has potential!
[/olist]

[h3]The dislike![/h3]
[olist]
    [*][b]Schism (The faction):[/b] This might be the most generic and boring take on a new faction I could have come up with in a HoMM game, period. Take a bunch of weird elves, add a few tentacles and eyes. Yea, allright, is that it? Lazy design and even though I am a fan of cosmic horror it could have been so much more interesting than tentacles and sleeping gods.   

    [*][b]The new grail-system:[/b] I hate it, truly. You have to cheese it since the opposing force is just your army + extra all. I personally actually like the old puzzle system with the monoliths since it gave an extra layer to the exploration. Was it perfect? No, but it is far better than this.

    [*][b]A ‚Äúmobile game‚Äù port?:[/b] I know this is a recurring complaint, and I thought it looked alright before I played the game properly. Now 10 hours later I can only chime in with the same sinking feeling. The graphics do not have the same crisp and clear details of the older titles, and some of the interfaces are just horrible. The whole thing looks like it could be downloaded on a random app-store and you are almost waiting for the microtransactions to pop up demanding cash to press the ‚Äúend turn‚Äù button..

    [*][b]The alchemical dust:[/b] I really did not like the addition of another resource that either forces you to destroy artifacts or be lucky enough to have a hut close by to forge dust from the other rare resources. Not a fan of this extra layer of scarcity modulated by luck and/or the faction you choose to play as...
[/olist]

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Now this is a demo, and a lot of these complaints might be void in the near future. I did not even comment on the randomly generated maps or the AI in this game since it feels moot point in a demo, but I really hope they step up their game with a bunch of carefully curated maps to enjoy in single players. However I have a sinking feeling that this will be another near miss in the HoMM-franchise, and while playing I kept coming back to the lingering thought, ‚ÄúWhy am I not just playing HoMM3?‚Äù. I see the love the devs are pouring into this game however and I have a feeling they will do their utmost to make this the best game they can. Will it be enough? Hopefully. 

Now I might never get the crystalline tesseract entity faction I long for, but maybe the dungeon will still be saved in the end? Time will tell, but for now I will stay on the side of caution and keep on recommending HoMM 3 over this tarnished copy.

Has promise, but the current look and feel of it is incredibly off.

pros:

They tried something new with the design and I have to say - a game called 'olden era' with a kinda mobile style like this.. I think that's not what people who played games like HoMM 2 or 3 wanted to see.

Art Design:
Some aspects of the game feel like a f2p mobile game - too many things fancy, over the top, many units just overdesigned to no end and it hurts my heart and eyes to see it becoming like this mess - especially the hero portraits look like straight out of an AI-image generator.

UI:
The UI is very clean and loveley made, quite a treat to look at.

Faction Perk System:
The law point system with the faction skill tree where you unlock upgrades for your adventure, ressource generation and creature-tiers is a nice idea, but this one-time-ressources feel a bit lackluster compared to creature- and adventure-booster - and mind that you can't have it all.. Additionally, it boosts only the creatures of your faction, which is fine, if all your towns are convertable to your faction, which is currently not the case.

Auto resolve:
I appreciate a fair auto-resolve system, but in fact, I often get way better result with auto-result than playing them manually = auto-resolving almost every battle, rushing through the whole map without doing a single battle sometimes. Of course it would be quite tideous to do every no-brainer battle for yourself with the same result, but playing battles manually, as it currently is, feel like a disadvantage to me, though it should be the core of the game. A hard miss, but I undestand that this is hard to balance. If it's too good, you don't do battles, if it's too bad, nobody will use it ever.

Army Size:
As in other newer HoMM-Titles, you can only have an army of 7 creatures, what makes it a bit of a pain in one-hero mode, where you may find base creatures in creature generators, but can't take them with you because you have your full city roster with you, all upgraded to the improved tier -> it would be nice to upgrade creature generators to select advanced units from there or how about extending the unit space to something like 10 - then you can also do more unit splits.

Movement:

Picking up items or ressources on the ground feels also kinda odd - first, ressources sometimes blend in very well in the washed out art style of other stuff, so it is sometimes easy to miss things visually. Additionally, you have to click on the -ground- of the object. so if the object is a bit higher than that one hex field they are placed at, you sometimes missclick to the space behind it instead of recognizing where my focus is. I mean, I get it, somehow you have to be able to move behind objects, but it really feels more an issue in this game than in previous ones - maybe it's that the world objects are a bit bigger than the Homm games I played, so missclicks thend to happen more often - would be really interesting if other testers feel this issue as well.

Unit Design:
Many units are just plain overdesigned to indistinctiveness and, sorry, mobile-game-sillyness.

One example is the Cavalry of the Temple line-up - the unit looks very silly, even almost goofy with all the wings and feathers on the knights armour, the lance looks like a soulless, random, oversized mobile game 'artifact weapon' instead of a lance and the unit proportions are completely off, rather looking like a Cosplayer on a Pony than a veteran battle hardened knight on a warhorse. Things like this add up and of course this is not the game, where the unit fancyness started, and it might sound a bit unfair to compare the artstyle of  the early titles like HoMM 2 from 1996 with todays style, but that's kind the point still: in earlier titles, the unit-design was -very- clean, clear and distinctive - maybe also because they had to be, but this game here feels like a mushy mess of indistinctiveness - washed out, fancy, sometimes unrealistic proportions, oversized items and especially weapons, too many extras and stuff. I am aware, that some people prefer this style over simplicity and clear art, but for me, it just doesn't look well like this. Especially advanced units portait differences are sometimes super minimal - hard to distinct.

Artifacts and Sets:
Many artefacts are a part of a set, which makes it interesting to collect more pieces. (in the end you pick up everything anyway, so it might also just be luck to get a set together or you try to trade it in at an artifact trader if you are really after it.

Missing stuff:
I really miss the town conversion feature in the demo. I want to win with my chosen faction, not being lucky or not to have more cities of my faction than my opponend does, basically determining if I can win as a high-stack-army or not by having more weekly unit production of my faction for my main hero or not.

Focus System and Creature Skills:
I don't like this system - it takes some time in battle until you have enough points to do something with your units, and then they are often already dead, decimated or the battle is over. Using units special abilities should be detached from this system - try cooldowns instead?, especially since this system is also connected with hero attacks, plus you are super limited with focus points maximum (I think it was 4 points).

Heroes:
The Heroes Magic and Hero attacks feel very lackluster - killing some few units with your hero attacks (which cost focus which your creatures need to to use their abilities) compared to killing hundreds with your units with just one attack just doesn't really scale well at the moment. getting +5 more damage when a single unit model has 100 or more hitpoints is quite a miss, even when multiplied in some ways with formulas I am not aware of.

Overall, the game has quite some improvements to previous titles, the QoL is good, but the art style really kills it for me, though the UI looks really clear and the battles are enjoyable. 

Quite some game systems just doesn't work well for me (law points, battle focus points, spell-scaling, alchemical dust ressource [to build/upgrade high tier buildings, to upgrade artifacts and to unlock new spells], mobile game unit design, ai-generator-like hero portraits)

A ‚Äúlarge‚Äù map now feels like what used to be a medium, and the ‚Äúextra large‚Äù is basically the old large.

But that‚Äôs not even the biggest problem ‚Äî it‚Äôs that there are plenty of good ideas that just didn‚Äôt land well.

For example, the two-tier unit upgrade system: you have a base unit, and then at the second stage you can choose between two different evolutions ‚Äî meaning you have to decide which direction to go. That part would actually be great: having to make a choice between, say, a level 2 archer who shoots twice, or one who deals full damage at any range. (That idea was originally from Disciples.)

But here‚Äôs the problem ‚Äî there‚Äôs no final decision. You can freely retrain units back and forth anytime, and it‚Äôs completely free. So the choice has no real tactical or strategic weight. Sure, in PvP it adds some flexibility, but only until people figure out what the meta is.

Then there‚Äôs the build tree, showing what buildings lead to what upgrades. That‚Äôs fine, it existed before too, but in the old games, for example, a level 2 town required four basic structures. Now, a level 2 town only needs one. There are only three town levels now instead of four, and the ‚Äúcapital‚Äù level ‚Äî the old Capitol ‚Äî is gone completely.

And then there are those classic, frustrating issues ‚Äî like the auto-combat system, which is completely incapable of making real tactical decisions. It just charges face-first into the enemy, losing ridiculous amounts of units in fights you could‚Äôve easily won without losing a single one.
Meanwhile, the enemy AI somehow plays perfectly ‚Äî no matter what army it has, it always makes the right moves. AI vs AI(neutral) battles always end the same way: the AI wins, losing only a handful of troops.

So the game basically creates ‚Äúchallenge‚Äù by giving the AI unfair advantages, rather than through smart design. Sure, that might be acceptable on higher difficulties ‚Äî but even on EASY mode, the AI is noticeably overpowered.
While you have to pick up every single resource on the map just to keep your economy running, the AI doesn‚Äôt gather anything at all and still manages to progress faster than you within a single week.

The new ‚ÄúAlchemist Powder‚Äù resource is another huge problem ‚Äî if you can‚Äôt collect enough, it can completely cripple your progress by week three. You can be completely locked out of upgrading or build, while the AI somehow fully upgrades its towns in two weeks without any visible source of that resource.

So yes ‚Äî the game feels unfair, and very obviously so. It‚Äôs a really bad design choice. If you can‚Äôt make a good AI, don‚Äôt just give it ridiculous hidden bonuses and call that ‚Äúchallenge.‚Äù
I honestly wonder if this is what they‚Äôre planning for the final release ‚Äî because if so, it‚Äôs going to be another failure in the HoMM legacy.

They did improve the visuals since the closed beta ‚Äî I‚Äôll give them that. It no longer looks like some dark fantasy mobile game.
But now there‚Äôs a new issue: so many interactable objects just blend into the environment so much that you can easily walk right past them without even noticing. Unless you keep spamming the ALT key constantly, you‚Äôll just stroll right by something important ‚Äî even an actual lumber mill.

I think I should start with a disclaimer: I've played every HoMM game, starting with the very first one when I was a kid. This is probably pretty obvious, as it would be very difficult to rate the game without playing whole series.

In my opinion, HoMM 3 is a game that should be pre-installed on every PC, like Klondike Solitaire or Minesweeper. But Olden Age has major problems, and the reason is not that it's "not like Heroes 3."

The series is objectively dead: Ubisoft, after acquiring the rights to the game, tried several times to restore it to its former glory. Clash of Heroes and Dark Messiah are excellent games in the Might and Magic universe, in my opinion, but overall, Heroes 5 is considered the last good numbered game.

Can Olden Age be considered a worthy continuation of the series?
Absolutely not, at least for now. For me it feels like a concept of a soft, save try to reboot the series. A chance to find out what players want in a new big-budget game and evaluate whether it's worth the effort and expense.

I'm confused by the fact that the developer in charge of the development is not very experienced (as far as I see, Unfrozen only have one game in their portfolio - Iratus), whether they can make not just a good game, but also a good game in a place where Ubisoft-led studios have failed remains to be seen.

I can note for myself that the game is trying too hard to be like Heroes 3 and 5 (75%/25%). I won't even describe the lack of some gameplay features, it's still a demo after all. Perhaps if we support their efforts now, we'll get something more in the future, but in recent years, players have increasingly been disappointed by the trust they place in developers and publishers.

I can see the developers' enthusiasm, their desire to create something new in the genre and the series as a whole, but desire and zeal alone aren't enough, and experience and skill are apparently lacking, because my main complaint isn't so much with the gameplay itself as with the gameplay decisions.

While playing, I couldn't shake the persistent feeling that I was playing a PC port of a mobile game ‚Äì weak, blurry graphics, poor animations, a terrible user interface, strange button placement, drawn-out battles, weak unit design, and the choice of in-game castles.

It's funny, but in this sense, Songs of Conquest or Age of Wonders 4 feels more like a proper sequel to HoMM than Olden Era itself. That's why I think the developers made the right decision by delaying the Early Access release. Heroes has a unique and dedicated community, which is why it's a very easy-going crowd that will settle for anything, but I think the series deserves a better approach, so please take criticism, improve, and refine the game, work with it as long as it needs to make a good game. Remember that BG3 showed everybody that devs, who were in close contact with the audience, managed to create an excellent and highly replayable game that players wanted.

When playing though -!and this is my most important critique!- it feels more like a bunch of chores and management that you have to do than actually a fun magical exploration, adventure and combat game. 

There are too many things you need to do each turn. And the loading time between turns, even if you have not discovered the enemy, is just way too long. The factions: Overall the different factions have cool towns. So again well done! However the units I have problems with. In general it is difficult to see what a unit does, how strong it is and if it has a ranged attack. This makes it hard to judge which fights to take. I mean if the jellyfish-looking unit is blue it shoots and if it's green or red it doesn‚Äôt. This makes no sense... Make it clearer! Also the human lvl 1 swordsman looks real strong, but turns out to be a lvl 1 trash unit. Come on, it has nice armour and a cool helmet, just to be a trash unit. Too bad, so sad. At least in HOMM3 you had pikemen and swordsmen clearly being as strong as they looked! And in general the units of the human faction are looking so bad! The "mighty" knights ride on ponies; what is this knight with a book and a mace, it looks ridiculous; the angels are meh; and what does this sorcerer lady do in this faction, this unit doesn‚Äôt fit with the style of the rest of the faction! Might be better to place her with the elves for example. The units of the other factions are also often weirdly designed. As others said, like your run-of-the-mill mobile game. Here, improvements would be had at this stage, but it is also where it is most necessary. Heroes games have rich lore and distinct units. Make them look serious and cool. Not whatever this is. Heroes 3 and 5 did much better.

Then the magic... it feels off and hard to follow; with spells that you can upgrade - but how does this combine with magic schools, spell power, mage guild level and wisdom. Its just messy...

The battles also could use improvement. The hex grid is great, but so sad that you don‚Äôt have those corners on the map like in HOMM3 where you could stand with a shooter protected by just 2 other units. Now it's harder to protect ranged units in from melee units... Overall the maps have too little terrain features to make battles feel different. The tactics option at the beginning of a fight should have an option to turn it off. In general it takes too many clicks in this game to do things. Tone those down and streamline them. The battles are alright all in all, not super exciting and a bit frustrating because of the difficulty identifying units and what they do‚Ä¶

The heroes look cool, that‚Äôs nice. They could perhaps be a bit more distinct per faction, but overall I'm not complaining.

Also how about getting the grail? It must be in there somewhere, but I feel I have missed it completely every time... are there hints? 

And then the music. It's all right. I hoped for more memorable music, more bangers. But perhaps we still get those in the main game. I also really hope the campaign has a good story (and not just destroy this conquer that).

Anyhow, I could say more, but this is it for now. I really hope this becomes a good game: the basics are there, but also big improvements are needed. The development team seems very passionate so I hope they make it work. Good luck!

It's a decent Heroes game, quite playable on small maps.
There are some flaws but for the biggest fun killers are two things:
- no grand battles
- new mechanics kill each other

No grand battles:
After one in-game month level 10 hero with 500 units just autowins everything on the map with zero losses. You just get overpowered with nothing to challenge you. By the time you get tier 5 spell you are already unbeatable and it has no use. Maybe I'm spoiled by playing H3 WoG where you can enable stronger neutrals with growing overtime but I remember fighting 30-50 tier 3 level 7 units, being a challenge even for level 20 hero. Or maybe it's because here neutrals don't have strong passive/active abilities...

New mechanics kill each other
CLASS. You can get an upgraded class by drafting 5 specific skills. You have 8 slots, hero usually starts with 2 skills, one of them is not class-based, so you need to draft 4 specific skills into 6 slots so there is low probability you you get such a chance. Also this means that you can only get 2 non-class-based skills which really breaks the idea of skill synergies.
FOCUS. Unit abilities consume focus points, so if you want to use them you need hero skills that generate more focus or decide which of them not to use or choose unit upgrades that don't have abilities. You can't just have 1 jinn that automatically give haste to another unit, because you may be unable to generate enough focus or you may have better abilities to use. There are units that can increase others speed and initiative, but it's most advantageous at the start of the battle when you don't have a focus point. What's worse some hero abilities use focus, as necromancer you can revive some units but it costs 3 focus points meaning that you have to forget about unit abilities, and even so if you have 3 unit stacks and fight one strong stack you won't generate enough focus before battle ends and can't cover significant losses.

Add here some other minor issues:
Magic feels underwhelming. Tier 1 lvl 1 spells feel useless, they just give +-10% unit damage or 1 speed. In H3 you could bless your lvl1 units to deal max damage instead of 1-3 range which is effectively +50% damage. And maxing corresponding hero skill spell school would allow you to use it on all units. And there bonuses for 1-2 round duration felt very good, especially on knight-type heroes with low magic power. But here... you need to upgrade specific spell using resource that is required for unlocking level 7 units, and there are some other things making good usage of magic so costly that it takes so much time to get enough upgrades that they are totally useless by that time.
Clunky UI for unit upgrade of hero visiting the city, or hiring units of same upgrade type that hero has without stationing hero in the city and back which costs movement points.
Hard to distinguish units that stay behind other units and have their model fully overlapped so sometimes you have to manually inspect several stacks to know what you're fighting.
And lots of other minor issues.

Overall it's a good start, the game seems fun and balanced enough on extra small maps where it takes less than a month until the final battle. But for something more complex it needs a lot of core mechanics to be completely reworked. And it needs a lot of quality of life updates.

I should probably revisit that part of the tutorial üôÑ
- I somehow feel like I'm missing .... hmmm.... not sure what the word it. Knowledge, information, overviews? I had a problem how to review this demo as Olden Era is still in development and there is no Steam's neutral review option.
While I enjoyed OE I am a singleplayer gamer first, so I decided to give "not recommended" review.

First pros:
+ It's not "a mobile" game, no matter what some desprate "fans" would want to you belive. It's fully HoMM game with its spirit. Sure, it's not HoMM3 game and hopefully will never be, as trying to emulate third part of franchise was never a successful idea.

+ I liked it. There still is "one more turn" feeling from the demo. Heroes development is a much improvement from H3's times but still need a lot of work.

+ Town screens have some issues but overall are beautiful and "live". You can see citizens moving around cities, something which was missing since HoMM1.

+ Alternative creature upgrades. Just like in last previous games, you can choose one of two alternatives and change them during gameplay.

+ Lots of spells and magic in the demo seems overpowered. They're not balanced yet and I find it's a good thing as nerfing things to the ground in search of mythical "balance" always leads to a game being boring.

+ New magic system. While you still get random spells in magic guilds, now you can pay to research/unlock missing ones. You can also can upgrade spells by using resources or by building more guilds (each additional doubled spell count as another spell's level).

+ Combat seems to be fun and units have a lot of nice and useful abilities. Same for each factions.

+ Lots of artifacts which can be upgraded to be even more powerful, althrough you won't have much resources to do that in short games/on a small maps.

+ Demo is very easly moddable and I guess the game will stay the same.


Now cons:
-  While there is "one more turn" syndrome, the game becomes boring very quickly. You test each faction, most of heroes, alternative upgrades, spells, etc. but after that, Olden Era doesn't have anything to hold you for any longer. Sure, it's a demo and not a full game but nevertheless you get bored very quickly.

- Maps. There are not maps per se but random templates focused on PvP aspect of game. They fail for singleplayers as while there have plenty places to visit with your heroes, their main focus is to destroy enemies ASAP. Each starting zone in a template is also a mirror of enemy's starting zone, so you know what to except. You also start with additional neutral (mostly) non-protected city or two in your zone, plenty of mines and creature dwellings, and lots and lot of resources to level up your city and army very quickly. That's very PvP mindset and there is no time to explore whole map unless you really want and prelong the game just to do this.

- While factions have unique units and mechanics, you play them as for now nearly the same. Sure, first week may be a little different but after that? Just gather your troops and roll out, crashing every enemy under feet of your army.

- Battles. Current autobattles are quicker and you lost less troops as the game can't calculate real losses and just make the number up. AI is still not good and only win if the player don't rush at it as it can then enmasse more creatures from external dwellings and castles.

- Lots of spell but not all are useful. Damage spells become less revelant as the game progress and overall they are weak. You also need to upgrade them to get their fully potential. While it's better than having "x magic" skill which makes a low level spell a mass version, it's still IMO inferior to magic system from HoMM2 and HoMM4, where mass spells were higher tier magic.

- Too many artifacts. Most of them are worthless (common and rare categories) and you don't have resources to upgrade them as you need these resources to ugrade buildings in your cities. Artifact sets are also underwelming and not worth to complete.

- Faction Law system. Basically a very limited research "tree" which you unlock with battles and town buildings. There is no relation between perks, so you only needd to unlock new level to be able to buy next perks. You can't buy them all so in the end you would always choose (nearly) the same laws. Laws UI is too small and ugly.

- Skills and heroes specializations. Some are overpowered, other not worth to bother. There are five sub-skills for each skill but you can only choose two and sometimes the choice is so obvious, you just wonder, how this even passed during game desing?

- Tragic UI. Too small and hard to read icons, icon colors that look nearly the same, buttons placed all around screen instead in one place, lack of information when you point mouse curson on it, lack of R-click options for many, many things, etc.

- Adventure Map readability. It's hard to tell which object is a map decoration and which is visitable. There are also resources you just can't notice because RNG placed them behind some rock or tree. There is an ALT key to highlight them but if you need to press a special key to see a map object, then something is wrong with your design.

- Creature and heroes design and portraits. It's hard to tell, which alternative upgrade you will fight and it was initially hard to tell, which creature you are buying. Fortunately devs changed a little that but the problem still exists. There is also a problem with portraits. Heroes portraits are hand-drawned (sometimes good, sometimes bad) but creature portraits are 3D in-game miniatures which IMO look worse. I think this clash of different graphic styles is the main reason why Olden Era is called "a mobile game". This and UI.

- PvP focus. It's clear to me this game is first and mostly focused on PvP games. Map templates instead of Random Generated Maps or scenarioes designed by humans/devs (althrough devs promised these features will be in final game), game mods for PvP players, game focus on combat and not enough of map exploration, heroes development, economy, etc., all these just point that devs focused on PvP aspect of HoMM games, especially HoMM3.

- Some red flags from devs behavior.
Early access was postponed IIRC twice and as for time of this review doesn't have a date.
There is also a case of devs calling themselves "true fans" - if you are a fan, you don't need to reasure yourself that you are "true" fan (do you need a certificate for this?).
I find also strange that for "true" fans devs sometimes behave like they didn't play other games than H2-3 and 5.
It's personal opinion but I have a feeling that Olden Era started on backbone of H7 and went from there to build its own self. It's nothing wrong in but many "new" features of OE were already present in H7 or even earlier but Unfrozen somehow "forgets" to aknowledge this.
On the other hand, Unfrozen really "hears" the fandom and make lots of changes so it's not that bad but nevertheless red flags are here and can't be ignore.
The last of red flags is that Might and Magic franchise is owned by Ubisoft and while I have some doubts in Unfrozen, I have many, many more doubts in Ubisoft and I fear they can screw the game just before the release (like introducing a DRM) and devs would have nothing to say in that case.

Overall I'm not against Olden Era and will see, how it would be developed futher but I don't recommend to pre-order or buy it in first day. Just wait and see.

This game takes inspiration from Heroes 5, and includes many changes introduced by it, but fails to bring the most important change: unit action rate (which was tracked in Heroes 5 by initiative). In this game units take turns acting, so a zombie acts as often as a dragon.

Some good features kept or introduced:

Units have two upgrades.
Hero skills have specialisations.
Heroes themselves can reach one of two potential masteries.
Items can be part of sets.
Hexagonal tiles in combat.
Many creatures have usable abilities.
Besides upgrading towns, players can also upgrade the realm. Some of these upgrades are shallow, but others can be game changers (for example, the ability to construct two buildings per turn)
Castle fortification upgrades can also specialise.
Items can be upgrades.
The graphical engine is really good.
I liked the draft hero build and follow up battle mode.

Some awful features, besides the lack of HMM5 initiative driven action rate:

The resource system was simplified, which is a trend in the age of games targeting the common denominator.
Combat maps are tiny.
In-combat tactical deployment is basic. Changes don't save between fights.
Creature dwelling units can not be recruited inside towns, like in HMM5.
Faction differences are token at best. Nothing like HMM5. The system could not have been made more shallow if the developers tried.
The art design suffers from a "samey" look for units, compounded by units having mostly the same size and the same narrow colour pallet...
The art design suffers from a bland colour pallet. This applies to the world and combat maps. Things blend in and tracking what can be interacted visually is exhausting. One has to keep Alt pressed at all time to highlight interactibles.
Combat unit abilities use a shared resource pool and have obnoxious cooldowns. Truly shameful compared to HMM5.
Hero skill specialisation are bland, shallow or both. Again, nothing like HMM5. The system was clearly an attempt at simplifying role playing and hero growth down to the mobile audience common denominator level.
Spells are bland or just awful, again nothing like HMM5 or even Heroes 3.

There were other features I liked or disliked, but these were minor.

At this stage, it is unlikely that changes will occur to the more critical issues shown above, hence why I do not recommend the game. Play the superior Heroes 5 Tribes of the East instead...

Instead of Evolution, and improving the already good aspects of Heroes, there is just so much that is literally driving me insane.
