I am writing this review as a massive HOMM3 fan, so perhaps it is doomed to be a bit biased from the very beginning. The game has generated a lot of hype recently and I do love the way they are promoting it, especially in terms of their YouTube channel. I do think that the creators have very big shoes to fill when creating a game for this franchise: it is very hard to encompass all the good things about the previous games while still trying to make it feel new, exciting and unique.

Graphics and UI
I did not like the style at the start at all, but it has grown on me a little bit‚Ä¶ I do have to agree with a lot of other gamers and say that it does look a bit ‚Äúmobilesque‚Äù. The graphics on the world screen seem too rich and detailed at times and I know it sounds silly but it just feels overwhelming at times. HOMM3 had that ‚Äúdark‚Äù feel to it that kind of made the game more serious. This one feels like it was designed for children. For me, it‚Äôs sometimes extremely hard to distinguish interactable objects from the background and I find that I would miss certain objects as they blend too much into the background. I never had that problem with any of the previous HOMM games. I would like to see a lot more sharpness in the design in this regard.

Towns
This is quite a disappointment for me in general as all towns sort of feel the same, just different colour pallets. In general, I think a lot of buildings look like figurines from some table top game, just looks fake and out of proportions. Towns also lack sharpness, I feel I‚Äôm not able to distinguish if a building is a dwelling or if its just background. Some dwellings have extremely poor designs as well, for example the Dungeon dragons live in some sort of a temple (?) that looks way too small to even house a single dragon‚Ä¶ Why not have giant caves in the back that you could zoom into and have them flying there in the background? I know it may seem too similar to other HOMM games but I think that would be hundred times better than the current tiny temple. For me, all towns just feel a bit cluttered and lack that grandeur that we all love from the earlier games.

Heroes
I would like to start by saying that I do like the variety of heroes and portrait designs that they have at the moment. Hero backgrounds are missing but I do feel like this is something that will come out eventually when the game is released as it‚Äôs probably one of the last things on the developers to-do-list (fair enough but I am hoping for decent stories and detailed backgrounds so we can fall in love with these heroes!). However, some heroes are clearly stronger than others and I feel like there‚Äôs a lot of imbalance currently. For example some heroes start with very powerful spells, while others have more limited abilities that may only be useful at the start or end-game. I think the worst part for me is the ones that specialise in units: at the moment, all heroes have the same stats and growth for the unit that they specialise in, e.g. the hero with Skeleton specialisation adds the same growth (+2) as the hero who specialises in Dread Knights (+2). Moreover, both of these heroes boost their specialised units stats by the same amounts, i.e. 1 speed, 1 initiative, 20% health and 1 attack/defence for every 3 hero levels. I think it needs a bit of balancing, especially for the growth part as +2 Skeletons/week surely does not equal +2 Dread Knights/week?
Another imbalance lies with the town specific hero abilities I think ‚Äì while I love the fact that heroes have a unique skill depending on their faction, I do not think that they are quite right at the moment. For example, Temple faction gets Ascension, which grants benefits whenever one of your stacks die. So in order to get a benefit, one or more of your stacks need to be completely wiped out first. If the stack does not die, no benefit. In reality, you will be forced to manage your units in a way so you have a lot of 1-unit-stacks so that you can maximise this skill. Might work well at the beginning of a game, but I am not sure how well this might go at late game. Sounds like a lot of micromanagement for me‚Ä¶ Other factions seem to have a lot more straight-forward passive abilities, that don‚Äôt really require you to do anything major, really.

Units
Visually, in general, I think a lot of units lack sharpness. A lot of them seem very detailed but it‚Äôs actually impossible to see all that detail in reality. What I mean by this is resolution and details seem out of proportions. For example, the Cavalry unit in the Temple faction looks like a cheap plastic figurine. Extremely poor design. It makes me not want to even recruit them, I can‚Äôt stand the current design! Other units, however, are quite well designed, like the Vampires or Angels. Sentinels of Glory though, seriously, what is that design? They have wings growing out of their hips it seems? No. In general, very hit and miss in terms of unit design.
Another thing I don‚Äôt like about the units is that the upgrades lack uniqueness in most cases. This game allows for two different upgrades for each unit but for some units it really doesn‚Äôt matter which upgrade you take, your choice will not have a big impact whatsoever. I think this is a missed opportunity really as they could have done something similar to HOMM4 where the choice of your upgrade was permanent and so it did really have a massive impact on your play style. At the very least, they could have made upgrades more different in terms making units melee/ranged, spell caster/ranged/melee, tank/assassin and so on. At the moment, most of the upgrades just feel very similar and boring, why even bother with two different upgrades in this case?
Unit abilities and the Focus mechanic, in my opinion, is a complete mess at the moment. While I do think the Focus mechanic is interesting, some units abilities are clearly better than others, so you will end up never using them, e.g. lower tier units versus high tier units. I think some Focus abilities should just be remade into passive abilities/spells to be honest.

Mage guild/magic
While I do like the current system overall, I think it has its weaknesses. For instance, spells can be unlocked for resources, which is fine, but the problem for me is that some spells are clearly stronger than others, so players will only unlock the main meta ones in reality. The randomness that came with the mage guild is something that provided that excitement I think in the previous games; in this one it just seems a bit too easy and too accessible. I miss the unpredictability!

Last thing I want to mention is something that I absolutely hate in the current version of the game, the Alchemical Dust. This is a super annoying resource that you can only find on the map, trade via a special building using your precious resources or gain by disenchanting artifacts. I played many maps at this stage and I never seem to have enough of this material, which is very frustrating, as this resource is required for certain town upgrades and also spell/artifact upgrades. I do honestly believe that exists only to add that ‚Äúgrind‚Äù factor to the game to make it more difficult and never ending. It‚Äôs a completely unnecessary aspect in my opinion. Either make it more abundant, especially in late games, or make it more precious to acquire but only needed for artifact upgrading. Also, some artifacts seem like they can be upgraded an unlimited amount of time, something I do not approve of. I like games to have finality, some sort of framework. Designing something to have no end I think only creates that unlimited grind possibility, something which I am not here for to be honest.

In general, I think it‚Äôs a very good attempt at a HOMM game but I do think it still needs a lot of work regarding different aspects of it. I have approx. 30 hours played at the moment and I am already bored. Will I buy the full version when it comes out? I honestly don‚Äôt know, perhaps when it‚Äôs on sale...
